FeedItems.Title: Announcing SignalR for ASP.NET Core Alpha 2
FeedItems.Summary: A few weeks ago we released the alpha1 version of SignalR for ASP.NET Core 2.0. Today we are pleased to announce a release of the alpha2 version of SignalR for ASP.NET Core 2.0. This release contains a number of changes (including API changes) and improvements. Notable Changes The JSON hub protocol now uses camel casing... Read more

FeedItems.Title: Announcing SignalR (alpha) for ASP.NET Core 2.0
FeedItems.Summary: Today we are glad to announce an alpha release of SignalR for ASP.NET Core 2.0. This is the first official preview release of a new SignalR that is compatible with ASP.NET Core. It consists of a server component, a .NET client targeting .NET Standard 2.0 and a JavaScript/TypeScript client. What’s New? SignalR for ASP.NET Core... Read more

FeedItems.Summary: By Juliet Daniel, Lucas Isaza, and Uma Lakshminarayan Have you always wanted to build a blog or other web application but haven’t had the time or educational resources to learn? With our blog template, available in our GitHub repo, you can create your web application fast and effortlessly, and even learn to master the new... Read more

FeedItems.Title: Getting Started with Windows Containers
FeedItems.Summary: Containers provide a way of running an application in a controlled environment, isolated from other applications running on the machine, and from the underlying infrastructure. They are a cost-effective way of abstracting away the machine, ensuring that the application runs in the same conditions, from development, to test, to production. Containers started in Linux, as... Read more

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Getting cryptic TypeScript errors while compiling C# aspnet project" (#2243) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm not sure where report the issue to (it's always hard to say with the new dotnet core) but I guess it's related to aspnet.
I have a aspnet core project which suddenly (yes, suddenly, I know it's lame, but) started failing to compile. I'm getting the following error:
Error	TS5023	Build:Unknown compiler option 'strictFunctionTypes'.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1203230/31569951-00c8e34a-b088-11e7-8547-ada309826e81.png)

I understand that it's from TypeScript. But why the hell TypeScript compiler is being call while I build C# project?! Yes, it's a web sdk project and yes, there're lots of *.ts files in wwwroot. But I don't need to compile any of ts files. I checked the csproj, it has nothing about "typescript".
I'm getting the error in VS and Rider but not in cli (`dotnet build`).
I'm just stuck. Please help.

Inside wwwroot I have:
wwwroot\client\typings\moment-duration-format\tsconfig.json 
where that `strictFunctionTypes` is used.
But.. who and why does call TS compiler?!

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Authorize] on both Controller and Method won't work with ASP.Net Core 2.0" (#2242) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Using ASP.Net Core 1, I had this this controller that had [Authorize] attrib so it would go to default schema which is Cookie in my case and then on some of its methods I would go [Authorize("Bearer")], so those specific ones would have Jwt Authentication enabled.

Now that I upgraded to ASP.Net Core v2, for those JWT enabled methods I'll get 302 even if I pass JWT. So the fix for me is to remove the [Authorize] attrib from class and put it on all methods, but this way it opens my controller to developers mistake that they might forget to add [Authorize] per method.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Two actions with same Http<Method> attributes result in ambiguity on ubuntu" (#2241) at aspnet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@distomin opened this here: https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/1026

uname -a
Linux N46JV 4.10.0-37-generic #41-Ubuntu SMP Fri Oct 6 20:20:37 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
dotnet --version
2.0.0
dotnet new webapi

Add 2 actions in a controller with the same attribute (HttpGet for example)
[HttpPost]
public Product Action4([FromForm]Product product)
[HttpPost]
public Product Action5([FromBody]Product product)

build the project, run the project and make http request.

fail: Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Internal.ActionSelector[1]
      Request matched multiple actions resulting in ambiguity
... Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.Internal.AmbiguousActionException: Multiple actions matched.

They say it works on Windows platform correctly.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Client fails to connect over WebSocket" (#1022) at aspnet/SignalR
Events.RelatedBody:
I know it's very early days, but I'm trialling SignalR Core (alpha2-final) in a small setup with 3 application/web servers and the Redis scale-out package.

I can connect with WebSocket to just one server, and with SSE/Long Polling to the scale-out environment.

In the single-server environment, the client can connect with WebSocket and receives messages/invocations once.

In the scale-out with SSE or Long Polling, the client receives the same message/invocation multiple times. I assume this is due to not having sticky sessions when load balancing.

In the scale-out with WebSocket, the client fails to connect.

Here's an extract of the logs from the scale-out environment with Docker [Swarm], and with a client that attempts to reconnect if the connection fails or is broken:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Hosting Http.Sys in production environment" (#6958) at aspnet/Mvc
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi Team,

Wanted to understand one thing. Let's say, I have written ASP.NET Core MVC application which is hosted on Http.Sys. Therefore, currently what I do, I navigate to published folder and there run **dotnet app.dll**. Server gets started and it starts to listen requests. However, this also opened dotnet console window, which is ok if I am doing development on local machine.

But, let's say I would like to take the published folder and deploy on server. Therefore, if I run the same command **dotnet app.dll**, server will get launched and start listening as well, I believe. But, it will have the same console window remain opened there. Is there any way to start the server as a background process, I mean server should keep running but cmd prompt shouldn't be there.

Thanks,
Rahul

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Url.Page() can not use path-based route if a custom route has been added" (#6957) at aspnet/Mvc
Events.RelatedBody:
After adding a custom route to my Index page, I am no longer able to generate URLs using the default path-based routes in Razor Pages.

Here is my custom route that allows me to add paging to the Index page, ie: `http://localhost:5000/page/2`

```
.AddRazorPagesOptions(options =>
{
    options.Conventions.AddPageRoute("/Index", "page/{pageNum}");
});
```

After adding that route, the following now returns null:
`Url.Page("/Index");`

Also, the following now throws *InvalidOperationException: No page named '/Index' matches the supplied values.*
`RedirectToPage("/Index");`

From what I can tell, this is the default behavior, based on the XML Documentation on the AddPageRoute method:
>The page can be routed via route in addition to the default set of path based routes. **All links generated for this page will use the specified route.**

Am I missing something, or is there no way to use the default path-based route after I start adding additional routes for a page?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "FormTagHelper support for asp-protocol (& asp-host)" (#6954) at aspnet/Mvc
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently the difference between the `AnchorTagHelper` and the `FormTagHelper` is the following:

|                    | Anchor | Forms |
|--------------------|--------|-------|
| asp-action         | ✔      | ✔     |
| asp-controller     | ✔      | ✔     |
| asp-area           | ✔      | ✔     |
| asp-page           | ✔      | ✔     |
| asp-page-handler   | ✔      | ✔     |
| asp-fragment       | ✔      | ✔     |
| asp-host           | ✔      |       |
| asp-protocol       | ✔      |       |
| asp-route          | ✔      | ✔     |
| asp-all-route-data | ✔      | ✔     |
| asp-route-*        | ✔      | ✔     |

Since the `AnchorTagHelper` supports protocol and host, I don't think it should be too difficult to add support for them in the `FormTagHelper`. If need be I can try to make a PR for it.

I needed the ability to set the protocol on a form (to create a absolute url), and while checking the documentation/source code I found that there wasn't currently support for it on the forms tag.

Should I create a PR, or is this omitted/disabled for a reason?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Suggestion: Support migrating to new Password Hashers over time" (#1466) at aspnet/Identity
Events.RelatedBody:
Over time, password hashes that were once considered secure are no longer considered so. Therefore, it would be desirable to be able to support multiple hashes in a single identity database, and transparently re-encrypt users' passwords as they login if a more secure hash function is available.

A newer hash function may mean a new algorithm (e.g. Argon2), or simply more iterations / different configuration parameters for the algorithm already in use.

A possible implementation would be:

1.  ASPNet the identity `UserManager` has a `PasswordHashers` property added, which is a list of `IPasswordHasher` objects in order of ascending secure-ness called `PasswordHashers`. The existing `PasswordHasher` property is changed to retrieve the last item in the list, and is made read-only, so that newly stored passwords use the latest hash function.

2. The  list index of the `PasswordHasher` that was used for a particular user is stored in a property of the `TUser` object called `PasswordHashVersion` 

3. During the authentication process, if the password check is successful, but the `PasswordHashVersion` value indicates it was not hashed using the current hasher, re-hash the password using the current `UserManager.PasswordHasher` and update the hash and version stored in the `TUser` object.

This would mean, over time, users still using the application would have their password encryption level upgraded and it would not be stuck at the quality of hashing algorithm available in the year they signed up. Users who no longer user the application would be stuck with the older password hashes. However, administrators could query the database to report on the number of users with legacy hashes, and contact them to request they sign-in to retain their account.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Best practice to integrate Identity into a multiple-layers project?" (#1465) at aspnet/Identity
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,

I have google/bing this but no good solution/suggestion found, as all examples just demonstrate the usage in one project, I'm wondering what's the best practice for integrate Identity with a real solution like below.

- UI Layer (MVC)
- Domain/Models Layer (i.e. `AppUser`, and we may want to keep this layer POCOs)
- Infrastructures Layers (i.e. `AppDbContext`)

In this case, we cannot define an `AppDbContext : IdentityDbContext<AppUser>` because` AppUser` is expected an `IdentityUser`, to make this work, we have to add reference to Identity stuffs to Domain layer.

I understand that if I re-implement all Identity Stores inside the Infrastructures layer, this would work, but this sounds not so good.

Is there a best practice that we can reuse majority of Identity and keep each layer clean?

It's very appreciated to hear your suggestion?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Design] Manage VisualStudioRazorParser lifetime." (#1722) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
- Exposed `VisualStudioRazorParser`, `DocumentStructureChangedEventArgs` and `ICanHasContextChangedListener` as ways to consume the new parser for a Razor document.
- Split the `VisualStudioRazorParser` into an abstract base and an implementation to avoid internal constructors.
- Changed the parser and corresponding smart indenter to take in document trackers, template engine factories and parser context change listeners. Of these additions the parser context change listeners will be deprecated once we own the TagHelper discovery mechanisms.
- Changed how the parser manages its internal parsing life cycle. It now creates template engines when the document tracker tells it to. So when project changes happen or new documents are opened the parser will re-instantiate its internal parsers to ensure that they're parsing against the correct configurations.
- Split the `VisualStudioDocumentTrackerFactory` into a provider and a factory. The provider exposes the old `GetTracker` methods where the factory is the text view connection listener implementation.
- Changed the code document provider to now use the parser provider in order to locate code documents associated with buffers. Prior to this that logic was hard coded.
- Removed old template engine reconstruction logic in the document tracker now that the parser owns that piece.

#1630

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Elegant way to get __RequestVerificationToken in razor page?" (#1719) at aspnet/Razor
Events.RelatedBody:
Use case: 
- My form tag is client based template, which means razor page won't know if my page have a form
- Ajax post method require 'RequestVerificationToken' header, otherwise it will return 400 bad request

Based on trick I found here
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46410716/example-ajax-call-back-to-an-asp-net-core-razor-page

I need to create a **fake** form tag with post method, which I did in the end
```<form method="post"></form>``` ---> This is very not elegant

Any other way to get RequestVerificationToken in elegant way?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "IEmailSender should have explicitly named parameters for html vs plain text" (#868) at aspnet/Templates
Events.RelatedBody:
There have been a number of people reporting bugs about the email confirmation link in the StarterWeb template not working.

This is happening because people implement IEmailSender and don't realize that the message being passed in is html. When they send the email as plain text the confirmation link does not work because of the url encoding.

I think the "message" parameter of SendEmailAsync should be renamed to htmlMessage and possibly should have an additional parameter for "plainTextMessage" and both should be passed in from AccountController.

This would make it more clear to implementors of IEmailSender what kind of string(s) they are dealing with and how to correctly implement it.

related issues:
https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2152
https://github.com/aspnet/Home/issues/2217

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Having multiple sites with the same IIS Express launch url causes VS to launch the wrong site" (#431) at aspnet/Tooling
Events.RelatedBody: The Security repo has three sample sites with the same launch url. (It needs to be the same because that url is registered with a remote auth server).  This can cause VS / IIS Express to launch the wrong site.

Events.RelatedBody:
`JsonPatchDocumentOfT.cs` will use the `ContractResolver` provided to get paths instead of forcing to lower case.

Addresses aspnet/JsonPatch#90.

See aspnet/JsonPatch for discussion.
